Abstract

The newly emerging federated learning (FL) framework offers a new way to train machine learning models in a privacy-preserving manner. However, traditional FL algorithms are based on an event-triggered aggregation, which suffers from stragglers and communication overhead issues. To address these issues, in this paper, we present a time-triggered FL algorithm (TT-Fed) over wireless networks, which is a generalized form of classic synchronous and asynchronous FL. Taking the constrained resource and unreliable nature of wireless communication into account, we jointly study the user selection and bandwidth optimization problem to minimize the FL training loss. To solve this joint optimization problem, we provide a thorough convergence analysis for TT-Fed. Based on the obtained analytical convergence upper bound, the optimization problem is decomposed into tractable sub-problems with respect to each global aggregation round, and finally solved by our proposed online search algorithm. Simulation results show that compared to asynchronous FL (FedAsync) and FL with asynchronous user tiers (FedAT) benchmarks, our proposed TT-Fed algorithm improves the converged test accuracy by up to 12.5% and 5%, respectively, under highly imbalanced and non-IID data, while substantially reducing the communication overhead.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, resource allocation, convergence analysis.

I Introduction

Over the past decades, portable smart devices with in-built high-definition sensors have gained access to an increasing amount of customized user data [2]. Trained via such massive data, machine learning-based applications provide a revolutionary way to distill information from these data resources and will continue thriving [3]. However, the training procedure often involves frequent data sharing to a data center or cloud, leading to a growing concern about the leakage of privacy-sensitive user data[4].

The newly emerging federated learning (FL) [5] is a promising solution for both privacy issues and resource-constrained data transmission problems [6, 7]. In FL, the learning task is solved in an iterative way by leveraging the local computation capabilities at users to train a shared model coordinated by the server, without sharing any user data [8, 9, 10]. The detailed steps of FL are: 1) at the beginning of each iteration, the server distributes the current global model to the selected users; 2) the selected users perform local updates using their local data sets in parallel based on the received global model and then upload local models to the server; 3) the server aggregates these local models to generate a new global model, and the iteration goes on until convergence.

Based on how the aggregation is triggered, FL can be classified into two categories: 1) Synchronous (Sync) FL [6, 11, 12, 13], where the global aggregation at the server is triggered until all updates from the selected users are received111Aggregation deadline may apply to avoid useless waiting for offline users.; 2) Asynchronous (Async) FL [8, 14, 15, 16], where the global aggregation at the server is triggered whenever an update from any selected user is received. Fig. 2 (please refer to page 8) shows the work-flow of Sync FL and Async FL, where each gray bar represents a local updating round for a specific user and the dashed lines represent the timings of global aggregations at the server.

Owing to the high communication efficiency gained in synchronized training settings, Sync FL algorithms are widely studied in wireless networks [17, 18, 19, 20, 21], and the main challenges of its wireless implementation lie in the resource-constrained and unreliable nature of wireless networks. Due to limited communication resource budgets, the user selection problem was studied to maximize the resource utilization with the focus on energy efficiency [17], training accuracy [19], training time[20], and etc. However, these works all assume that the uploaded models are successfully decoded at the server, and ignore the potential negative impact brought by the unreliable nature of wireless networks. Taking the practical transmission failure/error into consideration, the joint resource allocation and user selection problems were studied in [18, 21].

Despite its benefits in high communication efficiency, Sync FL can result in low training efficiency, since its convergence speed is limited by the slowest users, known as stragglers [22]. To handle the straggler issue, Async FL is a more flexible solution by allowing Async aggregation without waiting for the stragglers [23, 24]. However, Async FL has its own unique challenges, including: 1) the staleness problem, where the local model based on an old global model may be harmful to the current aggregation. This problem may be solved by applying a mixing function to exclude the users with â€œtoxicâ€ local updates [8]; 2) the computation bias, where faster users contribute more to the global model and lead to bias. This bias issue can be solved by introducing weight factors to control the influence of different users during the global aggregation step [14]; and 3) the high communication overhead, where the frequent information exchange between the user and the server can easily induce a communication bottleneck and result in low communication efficiency. The wireless implementation of Async FL is still in its infancy, and the above works did not consider the wireless settings.

To overcome the training efficiency drawback in Sync FL and the communication efficiency drawback in Async FL, grouping users into small tiers (or clusters) and aggregating their models with respect to each tier is a promising solution. The authors in [25] proposed a tier-based Sync FL, where users with similar computation delay are grouped and selected for aggregation to solve the straggler issue. Extending from [25], a multi-tier FL was first proposed in [26], namely FedAT, based on intra-tier aggregation in a Sync way and the inter-tier aggregation in an Async way. While promising, the above studies could result in unstable and degraded performance under highly non-IID user data, and they overlook the impact of wireless communication.

Notably, the aforementioned FL algorithms are all based on an event-triggered aggregation behavior, where the global aggregation occurs only if a specific event happens. This will lead to fluctuated global aggregation round durations, which not only causes stragglers in Sync FL, but also leads to unstable training results and high communication overhead in Async FL. Specifically, in Sync FL, since all updates from the selected users should be received before aggregation, the time duration of a global aggregation round is prolonged by waiting for stragglers, which results in low training efficiency. On the other extreme, in Async FL, since the global aggregation is triggered whenever a local update is received, those local models arrive at the server over different but similar time instances will trigger the global aggregation several times in a short duration, namely, aggregation glitch (An example is shown in Fig. 2, marked by the orange circle.). This is not desirable especially in highly non-IID data scenarios, as more local models would be required to merge into the global model to accelerate the training and to generate a more robust model. The hybrid multi-tier FedAT can alleviate the aggregation glitch to some degree, but still, it can not be solved fundamentally (As shown in Fig. 2, the aggregation glitch still exists in FedAT). Moreover, due to the Async inter-tier aggregation of FedAT, broadcasting can not be leveraged to distribute global model for users in different tiers.

To solve the above issues, one promising solution is to conduct global aggregation at a fixed time interval. This allows local models from users who managed to complete their local updating within the same interval to be aggregated together. By doing so, users are naturally partitioned into different tiers, and it is possible for the global model to be broadcast to users in different tiers for communication overhead reduction, as they are aligned at the beginning of their local updating round. We coin this solution as multi-tier time-triggered FL, which reaps the benefits of both Sync and Async FL. To our best knowledge, this is the first work that proposes a multi-tier time-triggered FL framework for wireless networks. Our major contributions are:

  • â€¢

    We propose a novel multi-tier time-triggered federated learning algorithm (TT-Fed) by including existing Sync and Async FL algorithms as special cases, with the aim to achieve a good balance between training and communication efficiencies. Specifically, the users are naturally grouped into multiple small tiers to alleviate the staleness problem among users. To control the computation bias, we also consider weighting factors for different tiers and design a novel global aggregation scheme.

  • â€¢

    We implement our proposed TT-Fed algorithm over resource-constrained and unreliable wireless networks. We formulate a joint user selection and bandwidth allocation problem for training loss minimization. To quantify the convergence, we perform a thorough convergence analysis for TT-Fed to obtain the analytical convergence upper bound for the training loss function. Next, we provide a sufficient condition for parameter setting, which ensures the convergence of TT-Fed. We further analyze in detail the impact of wireless communication and global aggregation round duration on the convergence speed and accuracy.

  • â€¢

    To solve the joint user selection and bandwidth allocation problem, we propose a decomposition strategy based on the above convergence analysis. Accordingly, the aforementioned optimization problem is decomposed into tractable sub-problems with respect to each global aggregation round, which is addressed by our proposed online search algorithm.

  • â€¢

    We evaluate the performance of TT-Fed in comparisons with three state-of-the-art FL algorithms, i.e., FedAvg, FedAsync, and FedAT, under various non-IID data and system parameter settings. Our simulation results demonstrate that under IID data setting, our proposed TT-Fed algorithm achieves similar test accuracy and convergence speed as other three existing FL algorithms; however, under highly imbalanced and non-IID data settings, our proposed TT-Fed algorithm obtains the fastest convergence speed and can improve the test accuracy by up to 12.5% and 5% compared to FedAsync and FedAT. Interestingly, we also show that the communication overheads follow FedAsync >> FedAT >> TT-Fed >> FedAvg, which means TT-Fed can substantially improve the communication efficiency compared to FedAsync and FedAT.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model. The convergence analysis of TT-Fed is given in Section III. The resource allocation problem is solved in Section IV, followed by numerical results in Section V. Section VI concludes this paper.

II-B Time-triggered Federated Learning (TT-Fed)

The work-flow of our proposed TT-Fed is shown in Fig.Â 2. Different from the event-triggered FL, the global aggregation in TT-Fed is triggered at every fixed global aggregation round duration Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T. Let us denote by Tğ‘‡T the time required for the slowest user to complete one single local updating round. Then, all users are naturally partitioned into Mğ‘€M = âŒˆTÎ”â€‹TâŒ‰ğ‘‡Î”ğ‘‡\lceil{\frac{T}{{\Delta T}}}\rceil tiers (âŒˆâ‹…âŒ‰â‹…\lceil\cdot\rceil is the ceiling function), with the first tier being the fastest tier and the Mğ‘€M-th tier being the slowest tier. Take an example as shown in Fig.Â 2, 4 users are naturally partitioned into 3 tiers according to the global aggregation round duration partitioning.

Let us denote by ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š{\cal{S}}_{m} the user set in the mğ‘šm-th tier. The tier index mâˆˆâ„³ğ‘šâ„³m\in{\cal{M}} (â„³=Î”{1,â€¦,M}superscriptÎ”â„³1â€¦ğ‘€{\cal{M}}\buildrel\Delta\over{=}\{1,\dots,M\}) captures how many global aggregation rounds are needed for users in ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š{\cal{S}}_{m} to complete a single local updating round. As shown in Fig. 2, user 1 and user 2 in the 1st tier (mğ‘šm=1) need a single global aggregation round (Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T) to complete their local updating, while user 4 in the 3rd tier (mğ‘šm=3) requires three global aggregation rounds (3â€‹Î”â€‹T3Î”ğ‘‡3\Delta T). Therefore, we have new updates from different tiers at each global aggregation round. Specifically, users in the mğ‘šm-th tier are ready to upload their local models in the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round, if and only if kmodm=0moduloğ‘˜ğ‘š0k\bmod m=0, where modmodulo\bmod denotes the modulo operation. As shown in Fig.Â 2, at the end of 2nd global aggregation round (kğ‘˜k=2), the server will receive local model updates from users in the 1st and 2nd tiers (i.e., mğ‘šm=1, 2), since kmodm=0moduloğ‘˜ğ‘š0k\bmod m=0, while no update from users in the 3rd tier (i.e., mğ‘šm=3) is observed due to kmodmâ‰ 0moduloğ‘˜ğ‘š0k\bmod m\neq 0.

The optimization goal of TT-Fed is the same as (1). The iterative training process contains four steps, namely, global model transmission, local computation, intra-tier aggregation, and global aggregation, which are detailed as follows:

(a) Global Model Transmission. At the beginning of the (k+1)ğ‘˜1(k+1)-th global aggregation round, the server only selects users in the set {ğ’®m|kmodm\{{\cal{S}}_{m}|k\bmod m= 0,âˆ€mâˆˆâ„³}\,\forall m\in{\cal{M}}\} to perform global model transmission. This is because these users uploaded their models in the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round and are ready for the next round.

(b) Local Computation. Since a selected user uâˆˆğ’®mğ‘¢subscriptğ’®ğ‘šu\in{\cal{S}}_{m} requires mğ‘šm global aggregation rounds to complete its local updating process, the uploaded local model at the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round is determined by the global model wGkâˆ’msubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGw^{k-m}_{\text{G}}. Thus, the local update of the uğ‘¢u-th user is

To balance the computation bias towards fast tiers, we adopt a heuristic weighting scheme [26]. We record the total number of updates from the mğ‘šm-th tier till the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round, which is âŒŠkmâŒ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘š\left\lfloor{\frac{k}{m}}\right\rfloor (âŒŠâ‹…âŒ‹â‹…\lfloor\cdot\rfloor denotes the floor function), and the total updates from all tiers, which is âˆ‘m=1MâŒŠkmâŒ‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€ğ‘˜ğ‘š\sum_{m=1}^{M}\left\lfloor{\frac{k}{m}}\right\rfloor. Intuitively, to balance the model bias, larger aggregation weights should be assigned to slower tiers, while smaller weights to faster tiers. Hence, the aggregation weight for models from the mğ‘šm-th tier at the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round is given by

Î±mk=âŒŠkM+1âˆ’mâŒ‹âˆ‘m=1MâŒŠkmâŒ‹,superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ‘€1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€ğ‘˜ğ‘š\displaystyle\alpha_{m}^{k}=\frac{\big{\lfloor}{\frac{k}{M+1-m}}\big{\rfloor}}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}\big{\lfloor}{\frac{k}{m}}\big{\rfloor}}, (10)

where âŒŠkM+1âˆ’mâŒ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘€1ğ‘š\big{\lfloor}{\frac{k}{M+1-m}}\big{\rfloor} is the number of updates from the (M+1âˆ’m)ğ‘€1ğ‘š(M+1-m)-th tier. The intuition is that we swap the update times of the mğ‘šm-th tier and the (M+1âˆ’m)ğ‘€1ğ‘š(M+1-m)-th tier, to control the impact from the faster one and to enhance the impact from the slower one.

In our proposed TT-Fed architecture, the global aggregation, intra-tier aggregation, and local computation are connected and interrelated. Due to this cascaded connection structure and time-triggered setting, only one model needs to be stored at the server. This is fundamentally different from the event-triggered multi-tier algorithm proposed in [26], where (M+1)ğ‘€1(M+1) models need to be maintained at the server in total, with one for each tier and one for the global model.

Sync FL and Async FL are special cases of TT-Fed. To be more specific, if we set the global aggregation round length Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T to be small enough, so that each user can be categorized into an independent tier, TT-Fed transforms to a fully Async FL. Under this circumstance, the server will update the global model whenever there is a local update. However, if we set Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T to be large enough (at least larger than Tğ‘‡T), this will result in a fully Sync setting. In such setting, users have to wait for all other users to finish local model uploading before aggregation. In this way, TT-Fed can transform into Sync and Async variations by tuning the global aggregation round duration Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T. Compared to Async FL and FedAT, TT-Fed allows users both in different tiers and in the same tier to align at the start of their local updating rounds, and thus, broadcast can be leveraged to enhance its communication efficiency. As shown in Fig. 2, at the beginning of the 3rd global aggregation round (Round 3), users in the 1st tier (user 1 and user 2) and the 2nd tier (user 3) are aligned to begin their local updating rounds. Meanwhile, as users with similar computation capabilities are grouped into smaller tiers, the straggler issues in Sync FL can be alleviated to a great extent. As shown in Fig. 2, waiting time for users in the 1st tier is largely reduced compared to that in Sync FL.

II-C Downlink & Uplink Transmissions

The downlink global model transmission takes place at the beginning of each global aggregation round via a broadcast channel. Thanks to the high transmit power of the server and the total bandwidth it can use for signal broadcasting, the time of downlink transmission is assumed to be negligible compared to that of the uplink.

The uplink local model transmission takes place before the end of each global aggregation round. We consider frequency domain multiple access (FDMA) for uplink transmission, where each selected user is allocated to a fraction of total bandwidth budget BğµB to upload their local model over different sub-channels to avoid mutual-interference. The bandwidth allocation vector at the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round among users is denoted by bâ†’k=[b1k,b2k,â€¦,bUk]superscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘˜â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ˆğ‘˜\vec{b}^{\,k}=[b_{1}^{k},b_{2}^{k},\dots,b_{U}^{k}]. We consider Rayleigh fading model [18], and denote guksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¢ğ‘˜g_{u}^{k} to be the channel coefficient between the uğ‘¢u-th user and the server during the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round:

guk=hukâ€‹lâ€‹(duk),superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¢ğ‘˜\displaystyle g_{u}^{k}=h_{u}^{k}\sqrt{l(d_{u}^{k})}, (11)

In (11), we consider non-singular path loss model lâ€‹(d)=minâ¡(1,dâˆ’Î±)ğ‘™ğ‘‘1superscriptğ‘‘ğ›¼l(d)=\min(1,d^{-\alpha}), with Î±â‰¥2ğ›¼2\alpha\geq 2 being the path loss factor.

II-E Computation Model

We assume the CPU frequency of the uğ‘¢u-th user to be fusubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¢f_{u} and denote by cusubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢c_{u} the number of CPU cycles required to process a single data sample. Hence, the computation time for the uğ‘¢u-th user to complete its local update in the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round is given by [17]

Ï„u,cpk=Î¶â€‹Duâ€‹cufu,subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¢cpğœsubscriptğ·ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¢\displaystyle\tau^{k}_{u,\text{cp}}=\zeta\frac{D_{u}c_{u}}{f_{u}}, (15)

where Î¶ğœ\zeta is the number of local training epochs. We limit the computation time to be mainly local computations, whereas the computation time at the server is ignored, considering the abundant computation resource at the server and the low complexity of global aggregation.

II-F Problem Formulation

An optimization problem is formulated to jointly perform bandwidth allocation and user selection, with the aim of minimizing the global loss function as

The minimization goal (16) is the global training loss. (16a) is the inherent constraint for user selection vector at the kğ‘˜k-th round, aâ†’k=Î”[a1k,a2k,â€¦,aUk]superscriptÎ”superscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘ˆ\vec{a}^{\,k}{\buildrel\Delta\over{=}}[{a}^{k}_{1},{a}^{k}_{2},...,{a}^{k}_{U}], where auk=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¢1a^{k}_{u}=1 means user uğ‘¢u is selected to update in the kğ‘˜k-th round, and auk=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¢0a^{k}_{u}=0 otherwise. (16d) ensures that a selected user can upload its local model before the aggregation deadline, where mâ€‹Î”â€‹Tğ‘šÎ”ğ‘‡m\Delta T stands for mğ‘šm training rounds required in total for user uâˆˆğ’®mğ‘¢subscriptğ’®ğ‘šu\in{\cal{S}}_{m} to complete a single local updating round.

Problem (P1) is a mixed integer programming problem. To solve it, we need to find an analytical expression of the optimization goal with respect to all the optimization variables. However, since the wireless channel and potential update tiers vary over different global aggregation rounds, it is impossible to find a tractable expression, making it impractical to solve (P1) directly.

III Convergence Analysis

To solve (P1), we start from the convergence analysis of TT-Fed to analyze how wireless communication affects its convergence speed and accuracy. To avoid tedious derivation and grab the main points, we assume that the user selection for each tier, and the bandwidth allocation for each selected user remains unchanged during the whole training process. We will revisit the user selection and bandwidth allocation problem in section IV, without the above assumptions.

For notation simplicity, we denote Fâ€‹(w)ğ¹ğ‘¤F(w) to be the global training loss as shown in (16). Denote by ğ’®m,S=Î”{u|aukâ€‹Ïuk=1,âˆ€uâˆˆğ’®m}superscriptÎ”subscriptğ’®ğ‘šSconditional-setğ‘¢formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘¢ğ‘˜1for-allğ‘¢subscriptğ’®ğ‘š{\cal{S}}_{m,\text{S}}\buildrel\Delta\over{=}\{u|a_{u}^{k}\rho_{u}^{k}=1,\forall u\in{\cal{S}}_{m}\} the users in the mğ‘šm-th tier who have successfully uploaded their parameters and ğ’®m,F=Î”ğ’®m\ğ’®m,SsuperscriptÎ”subscriptğ’®ğ‘šF\subscriptğ’®ğ‘šsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šS{\cal{S}}_{m,\text{F}}\buildrel\Delta\over{=}{\cal{S}}_{m}\backslash{\cal{S}}_{m,\text{S}} the rest of the users who have failed in uploading their models in the same tier. We denote the total number of data samples in sets ğ’®m,ğ’®m,S,ğ’®m,Fsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šSsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šF{\cal{S}}_{m},~{}{\cal{S}}_{m,\text{S}},{\cal{S}}_{m,\text{F}} to be Dmsubscriptğ·ğ‘šD_{m} = âˆ‘uâˆˆğ’®mDusubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ’®ğ‘šsubscriptğ·ğ‘¢\sum_{u\in{\cal{S}}_{m}}D_{u}, Dm,Ssubscriptğ·ğ‘šSD_{m,\text{S}} = âˆ‘uâˆˆğ’®maukâ€‹Ïukâ€‹Dusubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ’®ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘¢ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘¢\sum_{u\in{\cal{S}}_{m}}a_{u}^{k}\rho_{u}^{k}D_{u}, and Dm,Fsubscriptğ·ğ‘šFD_{m,\text{F}} = Dmâˆ’Dm,Ssubscriptğ·ğ‘šsubscriptğ·ğ‘šSD_{m}-D_{m,\text{S}}, respectively.

Before the convergence analysis, we make the following assumptions

  • â€¢

    The global loss function Fğ¹F is Lğ¿L-smooth, i.e. âˆ€x,yfor-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦\forall x,y:

    Fâ€‹(y)âˆ’Fâ€‹(x)â‰¤(yâˆ’x)âŠºâ€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)+L2â€‹â€–yâˆ’xâ€–2.ğ¹ğ‘¦ğ¹ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¥âŠºâˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿2superscriptnormğ‘¦ğ‘¥2\displaystyle F(y)-F(x)\leq(y-x)^{\intercal}\nabla F(x)+\frac{L}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}. (17)

    The smoothness assumption provides an assurance that the gradient does not change too quickly, so that the old gradient can provide us with useful information about a nearby new gradient if we take a small step.

  • â€¢

    Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convex, i.e. âˆ€x,yfor-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦\forall x,y:

    Fâ€‹(y)âˆ’Fâ€‹(x)â‰¥(yâˆ’x)âŠºâ€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)+Î¼2â€‹â€–yâˆ’xâ€–2.ğ¹ğ‘¦ğ¹ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¥âŠºâˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ‘¦ğ‘¥2\displaystyle F(y)-F(x)\geq(y-x)^{\intercal}\nabla F(x)+\frac{\mu}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}. (18)

    The convexity assumption allows us to transform the gradient information into distance-related information, which will make the mathematical derivation process more tractable.

  • â€¢

    Bounded local and global gradient dissimilarity, i.e.:

    â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(wGk;xu,i,yu,i)â€–2â‰¤Ï‡+Î½â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wGk)â€–2,superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜Gsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¢ğ‘–2ğœ’ğœˆsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜G2\displaystyle\|\nabla f(w^{k}_{\text{G}};x_{u,i},y_{u,i})\|^{2}\leq\chi+\nu\|\nabla F(w^{k}_{\text{G}})\|^{2}, (19)

    where Ï‡,Î½ğœ’ğœˆ\chi,\nu are positive constants. The above three assumptions are widely used in the convergence analysis for Sync FL, where the first two have been used in [28, 17] and the third assumption is used in [18] to characterize the dissimilarity of the local and global training loss at the same global aggregation round.

  • â€¢

    Bounded global gradient change within mâˆˆâ„³ğ‘šâ„³m\in{\cal{M}} training rounds, i.e.:

    (wGkâˆ’mâˆ’wGkâˆ’1)âŠºâ€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1GâŠºâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G\displaystyle(w^{k-m}_{\text{G}}-w^{k-1}_{\text{G}})^{\intercal}\nabla F(w^{k-1}_{\text{G}}) â‰¤Î´â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’1)â€–2,absentğ›¿superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G2\displaystyle\leq\delta\|\nabla F(w^{k-1}_{\text{G}})\|^{2}, (20)
    â€–wGkâˆ’mâˆ’wGkâˆ’1â€–normsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G\displaystyle\|w^{k-m}_{\text{G}}-w^{k-1}_{\text{G}}\| â‰¤Îµ,absentğœ€\displaystyle\leq\varepsilon, (21)

    where Î´ğ›¿\delta and Îµğœ€\varepsilon are positive constants. (20) can easily be satisfied based on (21) and Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, since the left hand side of the inequality is the inner product of directions (wGkâˆ’mâˆ’wGkâˆ’1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G(w^{k-m}_{\text{G}}-w^{k-1}_{\text{G}}) and âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’1)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G\nabla F(w^{k-1}_{\text{G}}).

  • â€¢

    Bounded local gradient within mâˆˆâ„³ğ‘šâ„³m\in{\cal{M}} training rounds, i.e.:

    â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’m)â€–â‰¤Î²â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’1)â€–,normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGğ›½normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1G\displaystyle\|\nabla f(w^{k-m}_{\text{G}})\|\leq\beta\|\nabla f(w^{k-1}_{\text{G}})\|, (22)
    â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(wGkâˆ’m)â€–â‰¤Ï•,normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1Gâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘šGitalic-Ï•\displaystyle\|\nabla f(w^{k-1}_{\text{G}})-\nabla f(w^{k-m}_{\text{G}})\|\leq\phi, (23)

    where Î²ğ›½\beta and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi are both positive constants. The above two assumptions ensure that the model changes within Mğ‘€M training rounds are bounded. Similar assumptions are commonly seen in the convergence analysis of Async FL [8, 26]. When M=1ğ‘€1M=1, TT-Fed transforms to Sync FL with only one tier. In this scenario, equations (20)-(23) are automatically satisfied with Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1, Î´=Îµ=Ï•=0ğ›¿ğœ€italic-Ï•0\delta=\varepsilon=\phi=0 and can be left out, meaning that the above assumptions are compatible to Sync settings.

The above assumptions can be readily satisfied by widely used loss functions. Moreover, although we assume Fğ¹F to be convex, our simulation results show TT-Fed works well under non-convex loss functions, e.g., cross-entropy of the neural network. The training loss of TT-Fed is upper bounded by the following theorem.

From Theorem 1, we can see that if 0â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î¾2â€‹Lâ€‹Î”2)â‰¤101ğœ‡ğœ‰2ğ¿subscriptÎ”210\leq(1-\frac{\mu\xi}{2L}\Delta_{2})\leq 1, then

This ensures that the convergence gap decreases as the number of training rounds increases. We note that Proposition 1 offers a sufficient instead of necessary condition. In other words, there are feasible hyperparameter settings that guarantee the convergence of TT-Fed, but Î¼â€‹Î¾2â€‹Lâ€‹Î”2ğœ‡ğœ‰2ğ¿subscriptÎ”2\frac{\mu\xi}{2L}\Delta_{2} does not fall in the range of (0,1)01(0,1).

Important insights can be gained from Theorem 1 on how wireless communication affects the convergence rate and accuracy of TT-Fed. As it can be seen from Proposition 1, the smaller the term (1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î¾2â€‹Lâ€‹Î”2)âˆˆ(0,1)1ğœ‡ğœ‰2ğ¿subscriptÎ”201(1-\frac{\mu\xi}{2L}\Delta_{2})\in(0,1), the faster the algorithm converges. To minimize this term means to maximize Î”2subscriptÎ”2\Delta_{2}, due to Î¼â€‹Î¾2â€‹Lâ‰¥0ğœ‡ğœ‰2ğ¿0\frac{\mu\xi}{2L}\geq 0. According to (26), this requires us to minimize the data sample amount of users who failed in uploading their models Dm,Fsubscriptğ·ğ‘šFD_{m,\text{F}}. Thus, Dm,Fsubscriptğ·ğ‘šFD_{m,\text{F}} reveals the impact of local updates uplink transmission on the convergence rate. Moreover, we know from Proposition 1 that the second term at the right hand side of (24) affects the convergence accuracy. As Kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¾K\to\infty, we have (29) hold. Thus, to enhance the convergence accuracy, the term Î”1â€‹LÎ¼â€‹Î”2subscriptÎ”1ğ¿ğœ‡subscriptÎ”2\frac{\Delta_{1}L}{\mu\Delta_{2}} should be minimized. This can be done by minimizing Î”1subscriptÎ”1\Delta_{1} while maximizing Î”2subscriptÎ”2\Delta_{2}. According to (25) and (26), this also requires us to minimize Dm,Fsubscriptğ·ğ‘šFD_{m,\text{F}}. Therefore, minimizing the number of unsuccessfully updated users is both helpful in boosting convergence rate and convergence accuracy. This obtained result is in line with the conclusions of existing works [10, 9, 29].

Remark 1. The obtained convergence analysis in Theorem 1 reveals how the number of tiers Mğ‘€M affects the convergence accuracy and the time needed for the algorithm to converge. As mentioned above, the term (1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î¾2â€‹Lâ€‹Î”2)1ğœ‡ğœ‰2ğ¿subscriptÎ”2\big{(}1-\frac{\mu\xi}{2L}\Delta_{2}\big{)} influences the convergence rate, while the term Î”1â€‹LÎ¼â€‹Î”2subscriptÎ”1ğ¿ğœ‡subscriptÎ”2\frac{\Delta_{1}L}{\mu\Delta_{2}} influences the convergence accuracy. To mitigate the negative impact brought by failed uploading of local models, we assume all users can successfully upload their local models, i.e., Dm,F=0subscriptğ·ğ‘šF0D_{m,\text{F}}=0.

For the special case of M=1ğ‘€1M=1, we have only one tier in the system, which is equivalent to Sync FL, hence Ï•=Îµ=Î´=0italic-Ï•ğœ€ğ›¿0\phi=\varepsilon=\delta=0. According to (25) and (26), Î”1subscriptÎ”1\Delta_{1} reaches its minimum and Î”2subscriptÎ”2\Delta_{2} reaches its maximum at the same time. Thus, the convergence accuracy can be maximized when Kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¾K\to\infty. This is as expected, because the models from all users are synchronized in each global aggregation round and the global model can gain the full-scale information from all users in each round. However, the global aggregation round interval Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T need to be large enough to include all users into the same tier, which is undesirable, since the existence of stragglers may prolong the whole convergence time.

For the special case of M=Uğ‘€ğ‘ˆM=U, we have only one user in each tier, which becomes Async FL. Under this scenario, the parameters Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi are forced to deviate a lot from 00, due to the difference in computation capability for each user. In other words, the local update from a slow user could be based on a fairly old global model, which may lead to a totally different or even opposite optimization direction to the current global model. Moreover, the non-IID data nature of FL intensifies this kind of deviation, and leads to degraded convergence accuracy. However, since the training interval Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T is very small, the straggler issue can be effectively solved.

In summary, if we carefully tune our global aggregation round partitioning, so that Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi do not deviate much from 00 and Î”â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡\Delta T is much smaller than Tğ‘‡T, it is possible to reap the gains in terms of both convergence accuracy and convergence time.

IV Resource Allocation for TT-Fed

In this section, we aim to decompose the intractable optimization problem (P1) into tractable sub-problems. We consider hyperparameter settings, which satisfy Proposition 1 to ensure the convergence of TT-Fed.

Suppose the training of TT-Fed terminates at training round Kğ¾K. Then, according to our convergence analysis in Section III, minimizing the optimization goal (16) of (P1) is equivalent to minimizing the convergence upper bound (24). Based on our analysis and Remark 1 in Section III, to minimize the convergence upper bound (24) and increase the convergence speed of TT-Fed, we need to increase the number of successfully transmitted users. Therefore, taking the aggregation weights and local data set sizes of different users into account, problem (P1) can be decomposed to sub-problem (PksubscriptPk\text{P}_{\text{k}}) for global aggregation round kğ‘˜k as

Clearly, although the optimization goal in (PksubscriptPk\text{P}_{\text{k}}) is simplified compared to problem (P1) and is decomposed with respect to a single global aggregation round, problem (PksubscriptPk\text{P}_{\text{k}}) is still a mixed integer programming problem. To solve it, we decouple this problem into user selection and resource allocation sub-problems respectively, and then propose an online search algorithm to solve the joint user selection and resource allocation problem in the following Algorithm 1.

We first optimize the bandwidth allocation under the fixed user selection vector aâ†’ksuperscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘˜\vec{a}^{\,k}.

Due to the scarcity of wireless network resources, if the total amount of allocated bandwidth for the selected users exceeds the budget, we need to exclude less important users in maximizing the optimization goal. On the other hand, given enough unallocated bandwidth, it is possible to include additional potential users to make the best use of resources. Hence, we propose an online user selection algorithm as Algorithm 1 based on optimum bandwidth allocation to solve problem (PksubscriptPk\text{P}_{\text{k}}). In steps 2 - 7 of Algorithm 1, we initialize the parameter settings for users in the qualified user set ğ’®qualksuperscriptsubscriptğ’®qualğ‘˜{\cal{S}}_{\text{qual}}^{k} that managed to complete their local updatings at the kğ‘˜k-th global aggregation round. In step 6, the optimum bandwidth allocation for each qualified user under unlimited bandwidth budget is obtained based on Theorem 2. Then, we calculate the contribution weight of each qualified user in maximizing the goal of (PksubscriptPk\text{P}_{\text{k}}). In steps 8 - 15, We iteratively select the qualified user with highest contribution weight until the total allocated bandwidth BallosubscriptğµalloB_{\text{allo}} reaches the bandwidth budget BğµB or all qualified users are selected.

The time complexity of the proposed resource allocation algorithm consists of two parts: 1) the optimum bandwidth allocation given by Theorem 2, whose time complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(U)ğ’ªğ‘ˆ\mathcal{O}(U); and 2) the online user selection algorithm given by Algorithm 1, whose worst case time complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(U2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘ˆ2\mathcal{O}(U^{2}), where each user forms an independent tier. Therefore, the total time complexity at the server side is in the order of ğ’ªâ€‹(U2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘ˆ2\mathcal{O}(U^{2}), and the space complexity is in the order of ğ’ªâ€‹(U)ğ’ªğ‘ˆ\mathcal{O}(U).

V Numerical Results

In the simulations, we consider a cellular network with coverage radius R=600â€‹mğ‘…600mR=600\rm{m}, inside which 20 users are randomly and uniformly distributed. The noise power spectrum density is N0=âˆ’174â€‹dâ€‹Bâ€‹m/Hzsubscriptğ‘0174dBmHzN_{0}=-174\rm{dBm/Hz} and we set the path loss factor as Î±=3.76ğ›¼3.76\alpha=3.76 [10]. The SNR threshold for successful decoding is Î³th=0â€‹dâ€‹Bsubscriptğ›¾th0dB\gamma_{\rm{th}}=0\rm{dB}. The transmit power of each user is set to be P=10â€‹mâ€‹Wğ‘ƒ10mWP=10\rm{mW} and the total bandwidth budget for uplink wireless transmission is B=20â€‹Mâ€‹Hâ€‹zğµ20MHzB=20\rm{MHz}. Each user trains a feedforward neural network (FNN) with a single hidden layer that contains 50 neurons using the cross-entropy loss function. We train the FNNs using different FL algorithms via a subset of the MNIST database [31], which contains 250025002500 equal sized 10 classes of 0-9 hand-written digit training images. The learned FL models are then evaluated on the test set of MNIST, which contains 10,0001000010,000 test images. Unless otherwise specified, the local CPU frequency of each user is 1â€‹Gâ€‹Hâ€‹z1GHz1\rm{GHz} and it requires 5Ã—1055superscript1055\times 10^{5} CPU cycles to process one data sample. We use 16 bits to represent each model parameter. For performance comparisons, we consider three state-of-the-art event-triggered FL algorithms as the benchmarks, namely, FedAvg in [6], FedAsync in [8] and FedAT in [26]. Their detailed training processes have been provided in Section II-A.

To characterize non-IID data behavior of users, we adopt two data distribution models [32]:

1) Heterogeneous data classes. We use the Dirichlet distribution qn=vnâˆ‘n=1Nvnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›q_{n}=\frac{v_{n}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}v_{n}} to characterize the varying data classes owned by different users [33, 34], where qnâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘ğ‘›01q_{n}\in[0,1] is a random variable denoting the share of the nğ‘›n-th data class, Nğ‘N is the number of total data classes, vnsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{n} is a Gamma-distributed random variable drawn from Gammaâ€‹(Î¸â€‹qÂ¯n,1)GammağœƒsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘›1\mathrm{Gamma}(\theta\bar{q}_{n},1) with Î¸ğœƒ\theta being the concentration parameter and qÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘›\bar{q}_{n} being the original distribution of class nğ‘›n in the whole system data set, i.e., qÂ¯n=0.1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘›0.1\bar{q}_{n}=0.1 for our constructed training set. The effect of different concentration parameter setting is shown in the left column of Fig. 4. We use different color bars to represent different data classes. It is observed that when Î¸â†’0â†’ğœƒ0\theta\to 0, each user will randomly possess only one class of data samples; while when Î¸â†’âˆâ†’ğœƒ\theta\to\infty, each user will possess equal sized data samples for each class.

2) Unbalanced data amounts. We use the Zipf distribution Du=Dâ€‹uâˆ’Î·âˆ‘uâˆˆğ’°uâˆ’Î·subscriptğ·ğ‘¢ğ·superscriptğ‘¢ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¢ğ’°superscriptğ‘¢ğœ‚D_{u}=\frac{Du^{-\eta}}{\sum_{u\in{\cal{U}}}u^{-\eta}} to characterize the different number of data samples owned by different users [35], where the parameter Î·ğœ‚\eta is used to characterize the skewness of the data set size for different user. The effect of different Zipf parameter setting is shown in the right column of Fig. 4. When Î·=0ğœ‚0\eta=0, each user will possess a data set with equal size DUğ·ğ‘ˆ\frac{D}{U}. Continue increasing Î·ğœ‚\eta will make user 1 possess most of the data samples in the network. When Î·â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‚\eta\to\infty, the local data set of user 1 contains all the data samples, whereas other users possess no data.

V-A Impact of data distribution

This subsection analyzes the impact of data distribution on the test accuracies of all considered FL algorithms. We set Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T for TT-Fed, so that the 20 users are naturally grouped into 2 tiers. For fair comparison, each tier in FedAT contains the same users as that in TT-Fed.

Fig. 4 shows the impact of unbalanced data amounts. The test accuracy comparisons of different FL algorithms are conducted under different Zipf parameter Î·ğœ‚\eta, whereas the concentration parameter is fixed Î¸â†’âˆâ†’ğœƒ\theta\to\infty, which means each user will possess different size of local data set with identical data class distribution. It is observed that, as the training time increases, the test accuracies of TT-Fed and the considered benchmarks increase and eventually converge to stable levels. Moreover, we notice that FedAsync converges quicker than all the other three algorithms under various Zipf parameters Î·ğœ‚\eta. This is because their global aggregation frequencies follow FedAsync >> FedAT >> TT-Fed >> FedAvg. When Î·ğœ‚\eta is small, i.e., Î·=0.35,0.6ğœ‚0.350.6\eta=0.35,~{}0.6, the convergence speeds and accuracies of these four algorithms are similar. This is because the computation delays among users are similar, and thus having more tiers is not beneficial. As Î·ğœ‚\eta increases, i.e., Î·=1,1.5ğœ‚11.5\eta=1,~{}1.5, the convergence speeds of FedAT, TT-Fed and FedAvg slow down, which is due to the intensified straggler issues. In summary, under highly skewed data set size setting with identical data class distribution, since the data set of a random user contains the full information of the global data class distribution, FL with more tiers obtains faster convergence speed.

Fig. 6 plots the impact of heterogeneous data classes. We compare the test accuracy of considered FL algorithms under various concentration parameter Î¸ğœƒ\theta, with Î·=0ğœ‚0\eta=0, which means each user has equal-sized local data set with skewed data class distribution specified by Î¸ğœƒ\theta. As each user possesses an equal-sized local data set, to characterize the difference in computation delay, the CPU frequency of each user is randomly drawn from the range of 1âˆ¼5â€‹GHzsimilar-to15GHz1\sim 5~{}\rm{GHz}.

When Î¸ğœƒ\theta is large, i.e., Î¸â†’âˆ,Î¸=100formulae-sequenceâ†’ğœƒğœƒ100\theta\to\infty,~{}\theta=100, each user possesses nearly evenly distributed data classes. In this case, FedAsync obtains the highest convergence speed. As Î¸ğœƒ\theta decreases, i.e., Î¸â†’0,Î¸=10formulae-sequenceâ†’ğœƒ0ğœƒ10\theta\to 0,~{}\theta=10, the convergence accuracies of all algorithms degrade with prolonged convergence time, which is due to the fact that under highly non-IID data the server needs more communication rounds to converge. Moreover, the learning curves of FedAsync and FedAT fluctuate. This is because the data class distribution at each user becomes more and more skewed, which means some data classes are too scarce or even missing. To have a smooth and robust learning curve, we need more information from more users for a single global aggregation step. As aggregation in FedAsync and FedAT involves fewer users and due to the existence of aggregation glitch in the event-triggered setting, updates from faster users/tiers tend to drift from the global optimum making the models not robust to skewed data. Without an efficient way to control the computation bias, the test accuracy of FedAsync is largely degraded under the highly skewed data setting.

Interestingly, even when the data class distribution becomes skewed, TT-Fed can still maintain fast convergence with robust performance, and achieve the highest accuracy. This is because the cross-tier synchronization and user grouping in TT-Fed can help gain more diverse information in a single global aggregation round and help yield a smoother learning curve compared to the event-triggered FedAT. Meanwhile, grouping users into smaller tiers can efficiently solve the straggler problem in Sync FL, yielding faster convergence. In summary, under highly skewed data distribution, i.e., Î¸â†’0â†’ğœƒ0\theta\to 0, TT-Fed can improve the converged test accuracy by up to 12.5% and 5% compared to FedAsync and FedAT.

V-B Communication Overhead Comparisons

Fig. 6 plots the communication overhead of the four FL algorithms under parameter settings Î¸â†’0,Î·=0formulae-sequenceâ†’ğœƒ0ğœ‚0\theta\to 0,~{}\eta=0, where the number of communication rounds required to reach the given target accuracy is shown. The CPU frequency of each user is randomly drawn from the range of 1âˆ¼5â€‹GHzsimilar-to15GHz1\sim 5~{}\rm{GHz}, and the global aggregation round duration of TT-Fed is Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T. For fair comparison, each tier in FedAT contains the same users as that in TT-Fed. From Fig. 6, we see that FedAsync requires larger number of communication rounds to reach a given target accuracy compared to its Sync counterpart (FedAvg). This is because in FedAsync the server has to frequently transmit the global model to whichever users ready for the next local updating round, whereas, in FedAvg users are synchronized at each global aggregation round, and model broadcasting can boost communication efficiency. Moreover, FedAsync suffers from severe computation bias which increases the number of communication rounds required to go from a lower target accuracy (i.e., 70%) to a higher one (i.e., 80%). Fig. 6 also shows that with the same tier partitioning, TT-Fed achieves improved communication efficiency compared to the event-triggered FedAT algorithm. This is because users in different tiers are aligned in TT-Fed to receive the global model via broadcasting, while in FedAT users in different tiers obtain the global model asynchronously.

V-C Impact of Training Round Partitioning

In Fig. 8, we examine how global aggregation round duration of TT-Fed affect its test accuracy under various data distributions. The simulations plot the test accuracies with 4 tiers (Î”â€‹T=0.3â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.3ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.3T), 3 tiers (Î”â€‹T=0.4â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.4ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.4T), 2 tiers (Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T, 0.8â€‹T0.8ğ‘‡0.8T) and single tier (Î”â€‹T=TÎ”ğ‘‡ğ‘‡\Delta T=T equals to Sync FL.). In Fig. 8 (a), the global aggregation round duration settings Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T and Î”â€‹T=TÎ”ğ‘‡ğ‘‡\Delta T=T both yields the highest test accuracy among all considered settings, while Î”â€‹T=0.3â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.3ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.3T yields the worst performance. In this case, the computation delay is similar for each user but data class distribution is highly skewed. Therefore, to ensure a good estimation of the global gradient, we need more users in a tier to guarantee that the data diversity is similar enough to the global data distribution. This explains why partitioning users into more tiers will suffer more from the skewed data class distribution. Second, with the same number of user tiers, the performance of Î”â€‹T=0.8â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.8ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.8T is degraded compared to Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T in Fig. 8 (a). This is because the global aggregation round length of Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T is smaller than that of Î”â€‹T=0.8â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.8ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.8T and the user are more evenly partitioned. In Fig. 8 (d), when Î·=1.5ğœ‚1.5\eta=1.5 and Î¸â†’âˆâ†’ğœƒ\theta\to\infty, partitioning users into more tiers is more beneficial (i.e., Î”â€‹T=0.3â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.3ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.3T). This is because a tier with fewer users contains enough information to generate a good estimation of the global gradient.

For Î·=0.45ğœ‚0.45\eta=0.45, Î¸=50ğœƒ50\theta=50 and Î·=1.5ğœ‚1.5\eta=1.5, Î¸=50ğœƒ50\theta=50 in Fig. 8 (a) (c), we see that partitioning users into more tiers is not always beneficial. This is because the data class distribution is highly skewed in these two scenarios, dividing users into many small tiers may yield biased gradient estimation for global loss function. However, when the differences in computation delay is large and data class distribution is similar, dividing users into smaller tiers will be beneficial (Î·=1.5ğœ‚1.5\eta=1.5, Î¸â†’âˆâ†’ğœƒ\theta\to\infty in Fig. 8 (d)). Interestingly, when the computation delay and data class distribution of users are similar (Î·=0.45ğœ‚0.45\eta=0.45, Î¸â†’âˆâ†’ğœƒ\theta\to\infty in Fig. 8 (b)), little gain can be obtained with more user tiers. In summary, the optimal global aggregation round duration setting in TT-Fed is the smallest one that generates unbiased estimate to the global information.

V-D Scheduling Policy Comparisons

Fig. 8 plots the test accuracies of TT-Fed under different resource allocation and user selection policies, with Î”â€‹T=0.6â€‹TÎ”ğ‘‡0.6ğ‘‡\Delta T=0.6T, Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1 and Î¸=100ğœƒ100\theta=100. For comparison purpose, the two used baselines are: a) equal bandwidth allocation with optimal user selection, and b) optimal bandwidth allocation and user selection under equal weighting (i.e., Î±mk=1Msuperscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘šğ‘˜1ğ‘€\alpha_{m}^{k}=\frac{1}{M}). From Fig. 8, we observe that our proposed resource allocation and user selection strategy outperforms both baselines a) and b) in convergence speed and accuracy. Compared to baseline a), the proposed bandwidth allocation algorithm can adapt to channel conditions of different users, so that the success probability of uplink model transmission is enhanced. Compared to baseline b), our proposed scheme can alleviate the computation bias imposed by frequent updates from fast tiers.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a multi-tier time-triggered FL algorithm (TT-Fed) for resource-limited and unreliable wireless networks. We formulated a joint user selection and bandwidth allocation problem with the aim of training loss minimization. To decompose this problem into tractable sub-problems, we provided a detailed convergence analysis and derived an analytical convergence upper bound for our proposed TT-Fed algorithm. Moreover, a sufficient condition was given to guarantee the convergence of TT-Fed. Finally, we proposed an online search algorithm to solve the formulated problem. Our simulation results showed that the proposed TT-Fed algorithm can achieve fast convergence with robust performance under highly non-IID data, while substantially reducing the communication overhead.
